awd_titl_txt: EAGER: Photo-Thermo-Chemical CO2 Reforming of CH4 by Concentrated Sunlight
awd_abstract_narration:
1548091(Li)

The study will explore the combined heat- and light-driven reaction of two greenhouse gases - carbon dioxide and methane - to produce carbon monoxide and hydrogen that can be used to generate fuels or chemicals while decreasing levels of greenhouse gases.  The unique aspect of the work is that the heat and light will be used simultaneously via a solar collector/heater to activate the carbon dioxide and methane reaction more effectively than by either heat or light alone.  The approach has potential to be used in remote or small-scale applications such as biogas generators or landfills where conventional fuel sources are not available.

The reaction between methane and carbon dioxide requires significant energy input to both activate the reactants and provide the thermodynamic driving force required for the endothermic reaction.  Sunlight provides a means to a favorable energy balance.  By use of a properly designed solar collector, optimized in wavelength and intensity to provide both direct photon activation and secondary thermal activation, the study will address the combined effectiveness of thermal and photonic energy input to drive the carbon dioxide - methane reaction.  This will be one of the first studies of its kind, and should provide important guidance into the relative effectiveness of the combined approach versus either thermal or photocatalytic approaches alone.  In addition, the study will develop catalysts that are specifically designed to utilize both thermal and photon energy sources, and it will also explore the mechanism of the combined photo-thermo-catalyzed reaction.

If the approach is successful, it could open the door to more catalytic reactions that could benefit from the combined thermo-photo approach.  These types of approaches rely on the sun for energy, and thus present a path to a more sustainable energy future as well as a means of mitigating greenhouse gas emissions or upgrading greenhouse gases to useful products.  The concept also fits well with treating gases in remote locations or from small-scale gas sources, where solar collectors and reactors can be utilized in modular form without the need for ancillary power sources.

por.por_cntn:
In this project, we aimed to use concentrated sunlight as the renewable energy source to convert two greenhouse gases carbon dioxide and methane to produce carbon monoxide and hydrogen, which can be used to generate liquid fuels or chemicals while decreasing the levels of greenhouse gases. The reaction between carbon dioxide and methane is called dry reforming of methane and it requires significant energy input to activate the reactants and provide the thermodynamic driving force required for the endothermic reaction. This research takes the advantage of the unique energy characteristics of sunlight, using the higher energy wavelength (e.g. ultraviolet) portion of the sunlight to drive photocatalytic reaction and the lower energy wavelengths portion (e.g. visible and infrared) to power the thermocatalytic reaction. The two effects, photo and thermo activations work simultaneously and synergistically to promote the overall DRM reaction efficiency and prolong the lifetime of catalysts used for this reaction.

Specifically we have carried out the following research tasks in this project. First, we have built a lab-scale concentrated solar reactor system that can reach up to 50 suns of irradiation intensity. Second, we have synthesized a series of unique catalysts that are promising for the synergistic photo and thermo activation effects. Third, we have measured the catalyst activity and validated the concept of synergistic photo-thermo-chemical activation. We found that this synergistic activation has resulted in one order of magnitude higher reaction activity compared to that with thermo-activation only, a significant discovery in this field. Finally, we have characterized the catalyst properties and correlated the materials property-performance relationship, which provides insight to the chemistry behind this unique activation process.

Findings from this project have opened the door to more catalytic reactions that could benefit from the combined thermo-photo approach. These types of approaches rely on the sun for energy, and thus present a path to a more sustainable energy future as well as a means of mitigating greenhouse gas emissions or upgrading greenhouse gases to useful products. This project has resulted the publication of one journal article and one master thesis, and has trained one postdoc and two graduate students. Education outreach activities were conducted in collaboration with the Enrichment Experiences in Engineering (E3) program of Texas A&M College of Engineering by training two high school chemistry teachers in a 2.5-week summer residential engineering research on the Texas A&M University College Station campus. The teachers have learned knowledge about to solar energy, greenhouse gases, and catalysis and gained hands-on experience in the research laboratory. They have also designed a chemistry lesson to teach in their classes after returning to their schools.  Through the above educational and outreach activities, this project has made broad impacts at the university and K-12 levels by increasing the awareness of global climate change and renewable fuels and by encouraging broadened participation in the activities of greenhouse gas control.
